questions.question_text:
The ORDERS table has a primary key constraint on the ORDER_ID column.

The ORDER_ITEMS table has a foreign key constraint on the ORDER_ID column, referencing the primary key of the ORDERS table.

The constraint is defined with ON DELETE CASCADE.

There are rows in the ORDERS table with an ORDER_TOTAL of less than 1000.

Which three DELETE statements execute successfully? (Choose three.)

choices.A:
SELECT cust_first_name, cust_credit_limit * .05 AS due_amount

FROM customers -
WHERE cust_income_level IS NOT NULL
AND cust_credit_limit IS NOT NULL
choices.B:
SELECT cust_first_name, cust_credit_limit * .05 AS due_amount

FROM customers -

WHERE cust_income_level <> NULL -
AND due_amount <> NULL;
choices.D:
SELECT cust_first_name, cust_credit_limit * .05 AS due_amount

FROM customers -

WHERE cust_income_level != NULL -
AND due_amount != NULL;
choices.C:
SELECT cust_first_name, cust_credit_limit * .05 AS due_amount

FROM customers -

WHERE cust_income_level != NULL -
AND cust_credit_level != NULL;
choices.E:
SELECT cust_first_name, cust_credit_limit * .05 AS due_amount

FROM customers -
WHERE cust_income_level IS NOT NULL
AND due_amount IS NOT NULL;

choices.D: One of the LONG columns must be changed to a VARCHAR2 or CLOB.
choices.C: The primary key constraint on EMP_ID must have a name.
choices.A: The foreign key constraint on DEPT_ID must be defined at the table level instead of the column level.
choices.B: The NOT NULL constraint on ENAME must be defined at the column level instead of the table level.
choices.E: The word CONSTRAINT in the foreign key constraint on DEPT_ID must be changed to FOREIGN KEY.

questions.question_text: Which two are true about unused columns? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Option B: "Unused columns retain their data until they are dropped."
This is correct. Unused columns keep their data until they are explicitly removed from the table. Setting a column to unused does not immediately delete its data; it only marks the column as unavailable.

Option C: "Once a column has been set to unused, a new column with the same name can be added to the table."
This is correct. Once a column is marked as unused, you can add a new column with the same name to the table, because the unused column is effectively 'removed' from the table’s structure in a logical sense.

Selected Answer: BC
Note on C: you can add the same name and data type as unused column even if it's not dropped. Tested and it works.

I tested, Unused can be added on primary key.
Desc does not display unused column. not does select query.

B C.
Note on C. You can only add a new column with the same name as long as it's a different data type until the UNUSED is dropped.

choices.C: Once a column has been set to unused, a new column with the same name can be added to the table.
choices.E: A primary key column cannot be set to unused.
choices.B: Unused columns retain their data until they are dropped.
choices.F: A foreign key column cannot be set to unused.
choices.D: The DESCRIBE command displays unused columns.
choices.A: A query can return data from unused columns, but no DML is possible on those columns.
